It has been demonstrated that the O-sulfonation activity in experimental animals correlated to the carcinogenic potency of N-OH-2AAF (34DeBaun J.R. Miller E.C. Miller J.A. Cancer Res. 1970; 30: 577-595PubMed Google Scholar). Investigation into the responsible enzyme in rat liver first revealed the aryl sulfotransferase IV (SULT1A1) to display activity toward N-OH-2AAF (17Sekura R.D. Jakoby W.B. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1981; 211: 352-359Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 18Ringer D.P. Norton T.R. Howell B.A. Cancer Res. 1990; 50: 5301-5307PubMed Google Scholar). A SULT1C1 sulfotransferase was later purified, characterized, and cloned from rat liver (19Gong D.-W. Ozawa S. Yamazoe Y. Kato R. J. Biochem. 1991; 110: 226-231Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 20Nagata K. Ozawa S. Miyata M. Shimada M. Gong D.-W. Yamazoe Y. Kato R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24720-24725Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The recombinant SULT1C1 sulfotransferase expressed in COS-1 cells was shown to exhibit a higher N-OH-2AAF-sulfonating activity than the SULT1A1 sulfotransferase (20Nagata K. Ozawa S. Miyata M. Shimada M. Gong D.-W. Yamazoe Y. Kato R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24720-24725Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Attempts to identify a homologous SULT1C1 sulfotransferase in human liver, however, have so far yielded no clear results (24Nagata K. Yoshinari K. Ozawa S. Yamazoe Y. Mutat. Res. 1997; 376: 267-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). Although the human SULT1C1 orthologue is still being sought after, two nucleotide sequences with high enough homology so as to be categorized in the SULT1C sulfotransferase subfamily (cf. Fig. 3) have been deposited in the EST data base (22Her C. Kaur G.P. Athwal R.S. Weinshilboum R.M. Genomics. 1997; 41: 467-470Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar,23Lennon G. Auffray C. Polymeropoulos M. Soares M.B. Genomics. 1996; 33: 151-152Crossref PubMed Scopus (1089) Google Scholar). Of these two new human sulfotransferase cDNAs (designated, respectively, 1 and 2), the SULT1C sulfotransferase 1 is a full-length clone, and the SULT1C sulfotransferase 2 is a truncated clone. In view of the potential differences between humans and rodents with regard to their constituent cytosolic sulfotransferases, we decided to clone these two novel human SULT1C sulfotransferases and express them for functional characterization. Analysis of the nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of the I.M.A.G.E. cDNA clone 302867 revealed the cDNA to encode only the C-terminal portion of a novel SULT1C sulfotransferase. As described under “Experimental Procedures,” we have prepared a DNA probe and used it to screen a human fetal lung cDNA library. A positive clone encompassing the 5′ region coding for the N-terminal portion was obtained. The nucleotide sequence determined for this latter cDNA clone, spanning nucleotide residues 1–1034 of the full-length sequence shown in Fig. 1, overlaps with that of the I.M.A.G.E. cDNA clone 302867, which spans nucleotide residues 849–2143. The authenticity of the full-length sequence was confirmed by the generation of a specific PCR product in a reverse transcriptase-PCR experiment using human fetal lung total RNA as the template in conjunction with sense and antisense oligonucleotide primers corresponding to the 5′- and 3′-terminal regions of the full-length sequence. As shown in Fig. 1, the open reading frame, beginning at base residue 330, encompasses 906 nucleotides and encodes a 302-amino acid polypeptide. The predicted molecular weight, 35,533, falls within the molecular weight range (33,000–36, 000) generally found for cytosolic sulfotransferase enzymes (1Mulder G.J. Jakoby W.B. Mulder G.J. Conjugation Reactions in Drug Metabolism. Taylor and Francis Ltd., London1990: 107-161Google Scholar, 2Falany C. Roth J.A. Jeffery E.H. Human Drug Metabolism: From Molecular Biology to Man. Springer-Verlag, Inc., Berlin1994: 45-78Google Scholar). The termination codon, located at nucleotide residues 1,236–1,238, is followed by a 905-nucleotide 3′-untranslated sequence that includes a poly(A) tract. Two polyadenylation signals (AATAAA) (35Proudfoot N.J. Brownlee G.G. Nature. 1975; 263: 211-214Crossref Scopus (1911) Google Scholar), located 670 and 59 nucleotides, respectively, upstream from the poly(A) tract are found. Kaur G.P. Athwal R.S. Weinshilboum R.M. Genomics. 1997; 41: 467-470Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar), rat SULT1C1 sulfotransferase (20Nagata K. Ozawa S. Miyata M. Shimada M. Gong D.-W. Yamazoe Y. Kato R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24720-24725Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), mouse SULT1C1 sulfotransferase, 3N. Hehonah, K. F. Windmill, L. Brix, and M. E. McManus, GenBank accession number AF026304. and rabbit SULT1C sulfotransferase 4H.-O. Tamura, Y. Harada, A. Miyawaki, K. Mikoshiba, and M. Matsui, GenBank accession number AF033653. (based on the WU-BLASTP + BEAUTY sequence similarity search). In comparison with the human SULT1C sulfotransferase 2, the deduced amino acid sequence of the human SULT1C sulfotransferase 1 (cf.Fig. 2) displays 63.7, 61.6, and 85.1% identity to the amino acid sequences of the rat SULT1C1 sulfotransferase (16Saeki Y. Sakakibara Y. Araki Y. Yanagisawa K. Suiko M. Nakajima H. Liu M.-C. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 124: 55-64Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar), mouse SULT1C1 sulfotransferase,3 and rabbit SULT1C sulfotransferase.4 The high percent identity value indicates that the rabbit SULT1C sulfotransferase is likely an orthologue of the human SULT1C sulfotransferase 1.Figure 2Amino acid sequence Comparison of the human SULT1C sulfotransferases with rat and mouse liver SULT1C1 sulfotransferases and rabbit stomach SULT1C sulfotransferase.Residues conserved among at least three of the five sulfotransferases are boxed.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) Fig. 2 shows the amino acid sequence alignment of the human SULT1C sulfotransferases with rat and mouse SULT1C1 sulfotransferases, as well as rabbit SULT1C sulfotransferase. Based on the sequence analysis data presented above, these SULT1C sulfotransferases can now be categorized into distinct phylogenetic groups as shown in the dendrogram presented in Fig. 3. The full-length cDNAs encoding the human SULT1C sulfotransferases 1 and 2 were individually subcloned into pGEX-2TK, a prokaryotic expression vector, for the expression of recombinant enzymes in E. coli. As shown inpanel A of Fig. 4, recombinant human SULT1C sulfotransferases 1 and 2, cleaved from their respective fusion proteins fractionated from the E. coli homogenates using glutathione-Sepharose, were shown to migrate at, respectively, 34- and 35-kDa positions upon SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The recombinant enzymes thus prepared were examined with respect to the immunologic cross-reactivity toward the antiserum against the rat liver SULT1C1 sulfotransferase. As shown in panel B of Fig. 4, the 34-kDa recombinant human SULT1C sulfotransferase 1 displayed a strong cross-reactivity toward the antiserum. The 35-kDa recombinant human SULT1C sulfotransferase 2, to a lesser extent, also displayed cross-reactivity toward the antiserum. The two recombinant SULT1C sulfotransferase enzymes were subjected to functional characterization with respect to their sulfotransferase activities. The activity data compiled in Table II revealed that both enzymes encoded by recombinant clones 1 and 2 catalyzed the sulfonation of p-nitrophenol but not dopamine. More importantly, the two enzymes displayed strong activities catalyzing the sulfonation ofN-hydroxy-2-acetylaminofluorene. To find clues to its functional involvementin vivo, the tissue-specific expression of the human SULT1C sulfotransferase 2 in different human tissues/organs was examined by employing the Northern blotting technique. It is pointed out that previous studies have demonstrated that human SULT1C sulfotransferase 1 is expressed in adult human stomach, kidney, and thyroid, as well as fetal kidney and liver (22Her C. Kaur G.P. Athwal R.S. Weinshilboum R.M. Genomics. 1997; 41: 467-470Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). By employing the reverse transcriptase-PCR technique, we were able to amplify SULT1C sulfotransferase 1-specific sequence using total RNA from human liver, lung, or intestine as the template (data not shown). The tissue-specific expression of human SULT1C sulfotransferases 2 was examined using aCLONTECH human mRNA master blot with the cloned cDNA as probes. As shown in Fig. 5, among the poly(A)+ RNA isolated from 50 human tissues, SULT1C sulfotransferases 2 was found to be expressed at higher levels in fetal lung and kidney and at lower levels in fetal heart, adult kidney, ovary, and spinal cord. These results on the tissue-specific expression may provide a foundation for the future investigation into the functional relevance of these new SULT1C sulfotransferases in different human tissues/organs. Because the SULT1C sulfotransferase enzymes are hypothesized to be involved in the bioactivation ofN-hydroxylated metabolites of carcinogenic/mutagenic arylamines and arylamides (17Sekura R.D. Jakoby W.B. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1981; 211: 352-359Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 18Ringer D.P. Norton T.R. Howell B.A. Cancer Res. 1990; 50: 5301-5307PubMed Google Scholar, 19Gong D.-W. Ozawa S. Yamazoe Y. Kato R. J. Biochem. 1991; 110: 226-231Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 20Nagata K. Ozawa S. Miyata M. Shimada M. Gong D.-W. Yamazoe Y. Kato R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24720-24725Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Kiehlbauch C.C. Lam Y.F. Ringer D.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 18941-18947Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), it will also be interesting to examine their relative abundance in normal versus tumor tissues. The results derived from the present study revealed that, in humans, there are multiple SULT1C sulfotransferases present in different tissues at possibly different developmental stages. These enzymes are likely to play essential, yet unknown, physiological roles at the developmental stages in the tissues where they are expressed. These enzymes, on the other hand, may also exhibit fortuitous sulfonating activities toward xenobiotic compounds such as arylamines or arylamides following their N-hydroxylation, thereby generating reactive intermediates that are capable of causing cytotoxic and genotoxic damage to cells in vivo. Such potential cytotoxic/genotoxic effects may pose a serious risk in view of the increasingly complex dietary food and the worsening environmental contamination. Another important issue is related to the species-specific differences in terms of the tissue specificity of the expression of the SULT1C sulfotransferase enzymes, which was first indicated indirectly by the differential O-sulfonating activities found in the livers of humans and experimental animals (38Abu-Zeid M. Yamazoe Y. Kato R. Carcinogenesis. 1992; 13: 1307-1314Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). One striking example is the difficulty in demonstrating the expression of the human orthologue of the rat liver SULT1C1 sulfotransferase. Futile attempts had previously been made to detect the specific mRNA in human liver, even though the sequence is now known to be present in the human genome (24Nagata K. Yoshinari K. Ozawa S. Yamazoe Y. Mutat. Res. 1997; 376: 267-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). That the mouse SULT1C1 sulfotransferase is expressed in olfactory cells (39Miyawaki A. Homma H. Tamura H. Matsui M. Mikoshiba K. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 2050-2055Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar) but not (at detectable level) in liver cells, 5Y. Sakakibara, K. Yanagisawa, J. Katafuchi, D. P. Ringer, Y. Takami, T. Nakayama, M. Suiko, and M.-C. Liu, unpublished results. seems to indicate possibly the differential tissue specificity of the expression of orthologous SULT1C1 sulfotransferases that function perhaps in distinct physiological context of individual animal species. On the other hand, however, the rabbit orthologue, with a similar organ (stomach) specificity of expression, of the human SULT1C sulfotransferase 1 investigated in the present study has recently been reported.3 More studies will be needed to clarify the similarities and differences between humans and other mammalian species in terms of their constituent sulfotransferase enzymes. Finally, it may be worthwhile mentioning that, compared with cytochromes P-450, cytosolic sulfotransferases, which were previously known as a group of Phase II drug-metabolizing enzymes, have received considerably less attention, and much fewer of them have been identified to date. The advancement of sulfotransferase molecular biology has allowed the convenient identification of potential sulfotransferase enzymes by searching through, in particular, the EST data base for the signature sequences (23Lennon G. Auffray C. Polymeropoulos M. Soares M.B. Genomics. 1996; 33: 151-152Crossref PubMed Scopus (1089) Google Scholar, 37Hillier L. Lennon G. Becker M. Bonaldo M. Chiapelli B. Chissoe S. Dietrich N. Dubuque T. Favello A. Gish W. Hawkins M. Hultman M. Kucaba T. Lacy M. Le M. Le N. Mardis E. Moore B. Morris M. Parsons J. Prange C. Rifkin L. Rohlfing T. Schellenberg K. Soares M. Tan F. Trevaskis E. Underwood K. Wohldman P. Waterson R. Wilson R. Marra M. Genome Res. 1996; 6: 807-828Crossref PubMed Scopus (389) Google Scholar) found for all known sulfotransferases. As the EST project continues to progress, it is anticipated that new members of this group of enzymes, which play important roles in not only the metabolism of drugs and xenobiotics but also the biotransformation of a variety of endogenous compounds, are bound to emerge. As exemplified by our present study, the major challenge then will probably be to elucidate the enzymatic characteristics and physiological involvements of these new sulfotransferase enzymes. We are grateful to Dr. Danuta Malejka-Giganti for the helpful advice and comments during the preparation of this manuscript and for providingN-hydroxy-2-acetylaminofluorene.

I sK, a slowly activating delayed rectifier K+ current through channels formed by the assembly of two channel proteins KvLQT1 and MinK, modulates the repolarization of cardiac action potentials. Mutations that map to theKvLQT1 and minK genes account for more than 50% of an inherited cardiac disorder, the Long QT syndrome (Splawski, I., Tristani-Firouzi, M., Lehmann, M. H., Sanguinetti, M. C., and Keating, M. T. (1997) Nat. Genet.17, 338–340). Despite the importance of these channels to human cardiac function, the molecular basis of their uniquely slow gating properties as well as the stoichiometry and interaction sites of these two subunits are still unclear. We have constructed several fusion channel proteins to begin investigating the stoichiometry of these two subunits and the role of voltage-dependent subunit assembly in channel gating. Functional properties of these constructs were measured using whole cell patch clamp recordings of transiently transfected Chinese hamster ovary cells. The constructs we tested are as follows: MK24 (C terminus of MinK linked to N terminus of KvLQT1); KK40 (a tandem homodimer of KvLQT1); and MKK44 (C terminus of MinK linked to N terminus of KK40). In control experiments (no DNA, control DNA, or only MinK), no time-dependent K+ current was observed. Expression of KvLQT1 or KK40 produced currents that activate and inactivate in a voltage-dependent manner as reported by others for KvLQT1. In contrast, expression of MK24 and MKK44 elicited current with activation kinetics and voltage dependence very similar to native I sK and identical to currents expressed by cells co-transfected with independent MinK and KvLQT1 cDNA. Expression of MK24 plus additional MinK significantly slows current kinetics. Our data raise the possibility 1) of multiple MinK/KvLQT1 stoichiometries and 2) indicate that uniquely slow kinetics ofI sK channels is due to voltage-dependent conformational changes of the channel protein and not to assembly of channel subunits. I sK, or MinK, a potassium channel protein sharing little similarity with other cloned potassium channels, induces very slow voltage-dependent K+ channel activity in Xenopus oocytes expression system (5Kaczmarek L.K. Blumenthal E.M. Physiol. Rev. 1997; 77: 627-641Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). It has only 130 amino acids and a single putative transmembrane domain. The cDNA coding for MinK was first cloned from rat kidney (6Takumi T. Ohkubo H. Nakanishi S. Science. 1988; 242: 1042-1045Crossref PubMed Scopus (420) Google Scholar) and subsequently from neonatal rat heart (7Folander K. Smith J.S. Antanavage J. Bennett C. Stein R.B. Swanson R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 2975-2979Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar). These cDNA clones exhibit identical protein sequences, indicating a possible absence of tissue-specific isoforms for this protein. Mouse heart MinK (8Honore E. Attali B. Romey G. Heurteaux C. Ricard P. Lesage F. Barhanin J. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 2805-2811Crossref PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar) and human heart (9Krafte D.S. Dugrenier N. Dillon K. Volberg W.A. Biophys. J. 1992; 61: A378Google Scholar) also show high sequence identity with the rat MinK protein, suggesting evolutionary conservation of biological function. Expression of MinK in Xenopus oocytes or in HEK293 cells can induce a unique slowly activating voltage-dependent K+-selective current that closely resembles nativeI sK, the slowly activating and non-inactivating K+ channel current well characterized in heart (5Kaczmarek L.K. Blumenthal E.M. Physiol. Rev. 1997; 77: 627-641Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar, 10Freeman L.C. Kass R.S. Circ. Res. 1993; 73: 968-973Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). Key experiments in Xenopus oocytes suggested that the MinK protein was a regulator of expressed channel activity and not sufficient by itself to form functional I sK channels (11Attali B. Guillemare E. Lesage F. Honore E. Romey G. Lazdunski M. Barhanin J. Nature. 1993; 365: 850-852Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar, 12Blumenthal E.M. Kaczmarek L.K. J. Neurosci. 1994; 14: 3097-3105Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). This work has been confirmed based on genetic linkage analysis of an inherited cardiac arrhythmia, the Long QT (LQT1)1 syndrome and positional cloning strategies (13Wang Q. Curran M.E. Splawski I. Burn T.C. Millholland J.M. Vanraay T.J. Shen J. Timothy K.W. Vincent G.M. Dejager T. Schwartz P.J. Towbin J.A. Moss A.J. Atkinson D.L. Landes G.M. Connors T.D. Keating M.T. Nat. Genet. 1996; 12: 17-23Crossref PubMed Scopus (1491) Google Scholar, 14Kass R.S. Circulation. 1997; 96: 1720-1721PubMed Google Scholar). Co-expression of KvLQT-1, a cardiac K+ channel linked to LQT1 with MinK, elicits membrane currents with properties of IsK (2Barhanin J. Lesage F. Guillemare E. Fink M. Lazdunski M. Romey G. Nature. 1996; 384: 78-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1385) Google Scholar, 3Sanguinetti M.C. Curran M.E. Zou A. Shen J. Spector P.S. Atkinson D.L. Keating M.T. Nature. 1996; 384: 80-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (1509) Google Scholar). The interaction of MinK with the KvLQT1 protein changes inactivation and activation properties of the assembled channels (4Tristani-Firouzi M. Sanguinetti M.C. J. Physiol. (Lond.). 1998; 510: 37-45Crossref Scopus (135) Google Scholar, 15Tzounopoulos T. Maylie J. Adelman J.P. Biophys. J. 1998; 74: 2299-2305Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar), and some experiments have suggested that MinK may affect permeation properties of the channel pore (16Romey G. Attali B. Chouabe C. Abitbol I. Guillemare E. Barhanin J. Lazdunski M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16713-16716Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar, 17Goldstein S.A.N. Miller C. Neuron. 1991; 7: 403-408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 18Tai K.K. Wang K.W. Goldstein S.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 1654-1658Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar, 19Tai K.K. Goldstein S.N. Nature. 1998; 391: 605-608Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar). However, questions remain about the stoichiometry of the MinK/KvLQT1 channels as well as the molecular basis for the uniquely slow gating of the functionalI sK channels. I sK gating kinetics are affected by the amount of MinK cRNA injected into Xenopus oocytes, (12Blumenthal E.M. Kaczmarek L.K. J. Neurosci. 1994; 14: 3097-3105Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 16Romey G. Attali B. Chouabe C. Abitbol I. Guillemare E. Barhanin J. Lazdunski M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16713-16716Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar) suggesting that the characteristically slow time course of I sKis due in part to assembly of MinK and KvLQT1 proteins. Chemical cross-linking of I sK protein also results in alteration in activation and deactivation kinetics (20Varnum M.D. Maylie J. Busch A. Adelman J.P. Neuron. 1995; 14: 407-412Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar), supporting the above hypothesis. Here we report experiments in which we have created tandem multimer channel constructs in which the MinK and KvLQT1 proteins have been fused in different configurations. These fusion proteins were designed to restrict protein interactions and thus contained minimal peptide linkers between the subunits. The purpose of these experiments was to test directly the hypothesis that the slow gating kinetics of expressedI sK channels is due to voltage-dependent assembly of MinK and MinK-free KvLQT1 proteins and to determine whether functional I sK channels are formed by unique MinK/KvLQT1 stoichiometries. CHO cells were transiently transfected with cDNA encoding fusion proteins of MinK and KvLQT1. Our results show that the kinetics of the MinK-KvLQT1 fusion proteins are identical to those of channels expressed in cells co-transfected with MinK and KvLQT1 cDNAs. This strongly suggests that the unique I sK kinetics are not due to voltage-dependent assembly of channel subunits in the cell membrane and are not rate-limited by the amount of MinK-free KvLQT1 subunit in the membrane. Instead, voltage-dependent conformational changes of the MinK-KvLQT1 complex can account for I sK activation kinetics. However, we additionally find that the channels formed by MinK-KvLQT1 tandem constructs can be further modulated by co-expression with additional monomeric MinK protein. This observation supports the view that the assembled MinK-KvLQT1 complex can be modulated by MinK protein and that multiple stoichiometries may exist for these subunits. Thus our data suggest that the MinK subunit may act as an allosteric regulator of I sK channel kinetics. The restriction enzymes were obtained from New England Biolabs (Beverly, MA) and Promega (Madison, WI). Pfu DNA polymerase (Stratagene (La Jolla, CA), was used in all PCR reactions to ensure sequence fidelity during amplification. Plasmid purification and fragment isolation kits were obtained from Qiagen (Santa Clarita, CA). The human cDNA clone KvLQT1 was a gift from Dr. M. Keating (Department of Human Genetics, University of Utah). The chemicals and reagents in the experiments were obtained from Sigma if not otherwise specified. A two-step PCR strategy was employed to construct human MinK-KvLQT1 fusion channel. All primer sequences are listed in Table I but described here. An oligonucleotide primer WFmK1 overlapping the C terminus of MinK and N terminus of KvLQT1 was paired with another oligonucleotide primer HRKv2 complementary to KvLQT1. These were used as primers in the first round PCR reaction to amplify the chimeric sequence MKv-1, composed of 27 base pairs of the C terminus of MinK (stop codon omitted) linked to the N terminus of KvLQT1 in frame. In the second round PCR, an equal molar mixture of MKv-1 and MinK was used as templates that were amplified by two outside primers, HFmNh3 and HRKv2. 10% Me2SO was added to all the reactions to overcome the high annealing temperature caused by higher GC contents in the sequences. The final product was cleaned up by “Wizard PCR Prep” (Promega).Table IThe oligonucleotides used in PCR and DNA  Open table in a new tab A three-way ligation was performed as the following: pCDNA3.1(−) (Invitrogen) was digested with NheI and BamHI; KvLQT1-pCDNA3 was digested with XhoI andBamHI, and the PCR product was digested with NheI and XhoI. The three fragments were mixed in a molar ratio of 1:3:3 in the ligation reaction. Construction of KvLQT1 into its homodimer KK40 was similar to the above approach. The primer pairs for KvLQT1 amplifications were WFKEc5 and HRKBm6, WFkBl7 and HRKHi8. All the PCR-amplified fragments were sequenced by the chain termination method in the DNA Sequencing Facility at Columbia University. KK40 was digested with XhoI, and the 2-kb insert was gel-purified and ligated into the XhoI site of MK24. Ligation was designed to ensure the correct orientation to form MKK44, with one MinK linked in frame to two copies of KvLQT1. The nomenclature used reflects both the relative contribution of each subunit as well as the insert size in pCDNA3.1(−). Thus MK24 reflects MinK:KvLQT1 = 1:1; vector, pCDNA 3.1(−); insert size, 2.4 kb; and MKK44 reflects MinK:KvLQT1 = 1:2; vector, pCDNA 3.1(−); insert size, 4.4 kb. All constructs were sequenced using mutagenesis primers and sequencing primers mk02–mk07, and the sequences were confirmed with the original cDNA sequences. CHO cells (ATCC) were cultured in Ham's F12 medium and transiently transfected using LipofectAMINE with and without LipofectAMINE-PLUS reagents (Life Technologies, Inc.). Cells were passaged the day before transfection at 50–70% confluence in 25-cm2 tissue culture flasks. Transfected cells were split and plated directly onto 35-mm plastic Petri dishes after 12–20 h and used for patch clamp analysis 48 h after transfection. Neonatal mouse ventricular cells were prepared and studied as previously reported by us (21Davies M.P. An R.H. Doevendans P. Kubalak S. Chien K.R. Kass R.S. Circ. Res. 1995; 78: 15-25Crossref Scopus (188) Google Scholar). External solutions contained (in mm) the following: NaCl 132, KCl 4.8, MgCl2 1.2, CaCl2 1, glucose 5, HEPES 10, pH 7.4. The internal solution contained (in mm) the following: K+ aspartate 110, CaCl2 1, HEPES 10, EGTA 11, MgCl2 1, K2ATP 5, pH 7.3 (KOH). Activation ofI sK was studied using a series of 2- or 5-s depolarizing pulses from −40 mV to different test potentials in the range of −40 to +80 mV (20-mV increments). Activation curves were determined by measuring time-dependent activating (pulse) or deactivating (tail) currents. Data were collected, stored, and analyzed on IBM-compatible computers interfaced to Axopatch 200A amplifiers driven by pCLAMP software (version 6, Axon Instruments, Burlingame, CA). Graphical and statistical data analyses were carried out using ORIGIN (5.0) software (Microcal, Northampton, MA). Recordings were carried out at room temperature. For comparison of multiple experiments, currents recorded during activation pulse sequences were normalized to the maximal current recorded (at +80 mV) and then averaged for each recording voltage. Where shown, averaged data are noted, and the number of experimental records averaged is indicated. The primary goal of our present study was to investigate the assembly and stoichiometry of the two channel subunits. In control experiments, we transfected CHO cells with no DNA (not illustrated), green fluorescent protein (22Marshall J. Molloy R. Moss G. Howe J. Hughes T. Neuron. 1995; 14: 211-215Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar) (Fig.1 A, n = 15), and MinK alone (Fig. 1 B, n = 14). For each condition, we found no time-dependent K+channel activity. Thus CHO cells do not have detectable endogenous KvLQT1 channel activity and constitute a feasible host system for this study. In contrast, CHO cells transfected with KvLQT1 cDNA (Fig.1 C) expressed time- and voltage-dependent current with properties similar to I KvLQT1 as described in the literature (2Barhanin J. Lesage F. Guillemare E. Fink M. Lazdunski M. Romey G. Nature. 1996; 384: 78-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1385) Google Scholar, 23Sanguinetti M.C. Curran M.E. Zou A. Shen J. Spector P.S.X.A.D. Keating M.T. Nature. 1996; 384: 80-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (1419) Google Scholar). I KvLQT1activates in a voltage-dependent manner and kinetics of activation become faster with increasingly positive voltages. The kinetics of deactivation (tail kinetics) are characterized by hooks (arrow) that reflect the removal of inactivation that had occurred during the preceding voltage pulse (24Tristani-Firouzi M. Sanguinetti M.C. J. Physiol. (Lond.). 1998; 510: 37-45Crossref Scopus (120) Google Scholar). Shaker family K+ channels are formed as homo- or heterotetramers (25MacKinnon R. Nature. 1991; 350: 232-235Crossref PubMed Scopus (764) Google Scholar, 26Hidalgo P. MacKinnon R. Science. 1995; 268: 307-310Crossref PubMed Scopus (425) Google Scholar) in which each subunit has six putative α-helical transmembrane segments and a consensus K+ pore region. Since KvLQT1 has the above predicted structure (23Sanguinetti M.C. Curran M.E. Zou A. Shen J. Spector P.S.X.A.D. Keating M.T. Nature. 1996; 384: 80-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (1419) Google Scholar), it should be possible to express I KvLQT1 by transfecting cells with cDNA encoding KvLQT1 fusion proteins of two or four KvLQT1 subunits. Currents expressed by cells transfected with KK40 were indistinguishable from currents encoded by KvLQT1 (Fig. 1 D), consistent with functional channels formed by multiples of the homodimers. These channels retain both the activation and inactivation (tail hook) properties of native KvLQT1 channels (compare Fig. 1,C and D). Thus, not surprisingly, the KvLQT1 channel structure resembles other Shaker K+channels. We next tested directly the functional properties of KvLQT1 and MinK multimers. First we constructed and studied the functional properties of the fusion channel proteins MK24 and MKK44. A general concern when such a fusion approach is adopted is whether the forced linkage ruptures the natural assembly of the channel, because the forced linkage may impose an unusual arrangement of the folding of and interactions between the domains of the channel and also influence expression of subunits (27McCormack K. Lin L. Sigworth F.J. Biophys. J. 1993; 65: 1740-1748Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). We were thus surprised to find that channels expressed from either MK24 and MKK44 strongly resemble wild type channel activity. Fig. 2 illustrates records for both constructs recorded in response to similar series of 2-s (upper row) and 5-s (lower row) voltage pulses and compares these with wild type MinK/KvLQT1 currents. Fig.3 summarizes voltage-dependent activation and kinetic properties of the constructs. As is the case for wild type MinK/KvLQT1, currents expressed by both fusion proteins activate slowly, and although the time course of activation becomes faster with depolarization, it never approaches that of the KvLQT1 channels (Fig. 3 B). Also consistent with co-expression of MinK and KvLQT1, channel activity expressed by the tandem multimers shows little evidence of inactivation either during voltage pulses or upon return to the holding potential (note lack of hook in deactivating tails).Figure 3Voltage dependence of activation and kinetics of channel constructs. The curves shown in these figures were determined from the normalized average data plotted in Figs. 1 and 2, and the numbers of experiments for each construct are indicated for those figures. Isochronal (2 s) activation curves, measured via analysis of current tails as described under “Experimental Procedures,” are shown in A. Currents were normalized to tail current measured after activation pulses to +80 mV for each construct. B, time to half-maximal time-dependent pulse current (measured as described under “Experimental Procedures”) versus activation pulse voltage. In both panels the following symbols are used: KvLQT1 (▪); KK40 (•); MinK + KvLQT1 (▴); MK24 (▾); and MKK44 (♦).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) KK40 and KvLQT1 channels share identical voltage-dependent activation gating properties (Fig. 3 A), and co-transfection of MinK and KvLQT1 shifts the voltage dependence of expressed KvLQT1 channel activation to more positive voltages as has been reported by others (23Sanguinetti M.C. Curran M.E. Zou A. Shen J. Spector P.S.X.A.D. Keating M.T. Nature. 1996; 384: 80-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (1419) Google Scholar, 28Barhanin J. Lesage F. Guillemare E. Fink M. Lazdunski M. Romey G. Nature. 1996; 384: 78-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (1298) Google Scholar). Furthermore, our results indicate that the voltage dependence of activation and the kinetics of the tandem constructs are the same as that of channels expressed by the MinK/KvLQT-1 monomers (Fig. 3, A and B), i.e. shifted to positive voltages relative to activation of KvLQT1 or KK40. Notice also that even in response to these very prolonged voltage steps, MK24 and MKK44 currents do not reach steady state for any of the channel constructs. This very slow activation process, which is characteristic of native I sK channel activity recorded in cardiac cells (29Kass R.S. Morad M. Ebashi S. Trautweiin W. Kurachi Y. Molecular Physiology and Pharmacology of Cardiac Ion Channels and Transporters. Kluwer Academic Publishers, Boston1996: 169-176Google Scholar), accounts for the failure of the 2-s isochronal activation curves for I sK and the tandem multimer constructs to saturate (Fig. 3 A). These findings support the view that the forced linkage does not grossly disrupt I sKheteromultimer channel formation. Additionally, the finding that the very slow activation gating kinetics of the expressed channel activity is conserved with the fusion proteins provides strong evidence that this characteristic of wild type I sK is not due to voltage-dependent assembly of MinK with MinK-free KvLQT1 proteins. The observation that MK24 and MKK44 equally resemble nativeI sK channels suggests that the stoichiometry of the two proteins may not be fixed in the assembled I sKchannel, an atypical scenario for channel subunit interactions in general (30Catterall W.A. Science. 1991; 253: 1499-1500Crossref PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar) but one previously suggested by others forI sK (31Cui J. Kline R.P. Pennefather P. Cohen I.S. J. Gen. Physiol. 1994; 104: 87-105Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 32Romey G. Attali B. Chouabe C. Abitbol I. Guillemare E. Barhanin J. Lazdunski M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16713-16716Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). Thus, it is highly possible that there is a minimal stoichiometry requirement for incorporation of MinK that modifies KvLQT1 gating such that expressed currents resembleI sK. This relationship would be supported by the expressed MKK44 channel activity. In support of this hypothesis is an earlier study in which 2 MinK monomers were suggested to associate with other, then unidentified, non-MinK subunits to form functionalI sK channels in Xenopus oocytes (33Wang K.W. Goldstein S.A. Neuron. 1995; 14: 1303-1309Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar). How is it thus possible to detect multiple MinK and KvLQT1 stoichiometries? One approach is to test for changes in multimericI sK channel activity by co-expression with additional MinK protein. Thus, to investigate whether the fusion proteins MK24 and MKK44 could also be modulated by additional MinK, we co-expressed MinK with the above constructs and characterized the expressed channel activity. If MinK slows the kinetics of the fusion protein, this effect cannot be due to depletion of MinK-free KvLQT1 as previously suggested by others ((32, 34) but instead must be due to additional modulation of the assembled fusion protein. Co-transfection with additional MinK slows MK24 activation kinetics (Fig.4). In order to quantify this difference, we measured the time to attain half-maximal current (t 12) for each construct and each current measurement. Shown in Fig. 4 D is a summary of this analysis for the influence of MinK co-transfection on t 12for MK24 for measurements at +60 mV. Co-transfection with MinK causes a significant (p < 0.001) difference int 12 for MK24 channels. Interestingly, deactivation kinetics of MK24 are not affected by MinK co-transfection as is evidenced by deactivation tail records shown in Fig. 4, Band C. The slowing of MK24 activation kinetics illustrated at one voltage in Fig. 4 occurs over the entire range of activation (Fig.5 B). In addition, co-expression of MinK with MK24 further alters the voltage dependence of activation as evidenced by the MinK-induced changes in the isochronal activation curve illustrated in Fig. 5 A. These data indicate that additional MinK protein(s) are able to interact with the MinK-KvLQT1 fusion protein MK24, and this interaction specifically alters channel activation but not deactivation kinetics. Also shown for comparison in Fig. 5 are comparable activation (A) and kinetic (B) data for IsK measured in neonatal mouse ventricular cells (21Davies M.P. An R.H. Doevendans P. Kubalak S. Chien K.R. Kass R.S. Circ. Res. 1995; 78: 15-25Crossref Scopus (188) Google Scholar). These data, plotted asopen circles in both panels, are remarkably similar to MinK-KvLQT1 and the MK24 data but are distinct from MK24 + MinK data, strongly suggesting that native IsK channels in cardiac cells assemble with a minimum MinK-KvLQT1 stoichiometry. Our results clearly show that the unique functional properties conferred upon KvLQ1 by incorporation of MinK protein are due to differences in voltage-dependent conformational changes of the assembled MinK-KvLQT1 protein complex. Furthermore, we find that MinK can alter the voltage-dependent gating and kinetic properties of tandem multimer complexes strongly suggesting the existence of more than one MinK/KvLQT1 stoichiometry. Work by others has suggested that MinK lines the pore the of I sKchannel, modifying its permeability (18Tai K.K. Wang K.W. Goldstein S.A. J. Biol. Neuron. 1996; 16: 571-577Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar) and single channel properties (32Romey G. Attali B. Chouabe C. Abitbol I. Guillemare E. Barhanin J. Lazdunski M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 16713-16716Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar) of the expressed channels. Structural analysis of the potassium channel from Streptomyces lividans, which has sequence similarity to KvLQT1 in the P region, raises the possibility that MinK modulation may arise from interactions outside of the KvLQT1 pore (37Doyle D.A. Cabral J.M. Pfuetzner R.A. Kuo A. Gulbis J.M. Cohen S.L. Chait B.T. MacKinnon R. Science. 1998; 280: 69-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (5701) Google Scholar). In contrast, channel gating is a dynamic process, the basis for which structural data are not yet available. Our data showing that MinK modulates the MK24 fusion protein raise the interesting possibility that modulation of gating kinetics may involve interaction sites peripheral to the channel pore and that functional changes in channel activity are the result of allosteric modulation of the channel protein. How the MinK protein confers these properties upon the assembled channel and the identification of key interaction sites that underlie these functional changes remain to be determined. Future experiments in which we restrict the linkage to and size of the MinK construct should be very useful in identifying these residues as well as their biophysical roles. Drugs that target the KvLQT-1-MinK complex, blockers ofI sK, have been developed as Class III anti-arrhythmic drugs (38Kass R.S. Zipes D. Jalife J. Cardiac Electrophysiology. W. B. Saunders Co., Philadelphia1994: 74-82Google Scholar). Recently, the action of these compounds has been found to be dependent on the interactions between KvLQT1 and MinK proteins (39Busch A.E. Busch G.L. Ford E. Suessbrich H. Lang H.J. Greger R. Kunzelmann Attali B. Stuhmer W. Br. J. Pharmacol. 1997; 122: 187-189Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). Hence the fusion proteins developed in the present study should prove to be powerful tools in sorting out the molecular mechanisms of these drugs and modifying their activity by targeting key MinK/KvLQT1 interaction domains. We thank Drs. S. A. Siegelbaum, A. R. Marks, and B. Heath for discussion and helpful suggestions.

The power of genetic engineering methods, along with increasing genomic information, makes heterologous expression of proteins an extremely important biochemical tool. Unfortunately, proteins obtained in this way often are not in their native form, and folding becomes a crucial step in protein production. We have recently developed a strategy that promotes the folding of chemically denatured proteins via the sequential addition of low molecular weight “artificial chaperones.” Here we describe in detail the application of this method to porcine heart citrate synthase. Refolding yields of as high as 65% have been achieved. Mechanistic studies indicate that there are significant differences between artificial chaperone-assisted refolding of citrate synthase and artificial chaperone-assisted refolding of two other proteins that have been examined, carbonic anhydrase B (Rozema, D., and Gellman, S. H. (1996) J. Biol. Chem. 271, 3478–3487) and lysozyme (Rozema, D., and Gellman, S. H. (1996) Biochemistry 35, 15760–15771). The differences among these three test proteins reveal the range of procedural variation that must be considered in the application of the artificial chaperone method to new proteins. H. (1996) J. Biol. Chem. 271, 3478–3487) and lysozyme (Rozema, D., and Gellman, S. H. (1996) Biochemistry 35, 15760–15771). The development of genetic engineering techniques for overexpression of heterologous proteins has increased interest in the practical aspects of protein refolding (1$$Google Scholar, 2$$Google Scholar, 3Jaenicke R. Seckler R. Adv. Protein Chem. 1997; 50: 1-59Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4DeBernardez-Clark E. Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. 1998; 9: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (401) Google Scholar, 5Fink A.L. Folding Design. 1998; 3: R9-R23Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1025) Google Scholar). Both basic protein science and biotechnological applications require that the overexpressed protein attain the correctly folded conformation. This requirement can be particularly daunting if the protein is initially obtained as inclusion bodies, a result that is common in bacterial expression systems. We have recently developed a protein folding strategy that was inspired by the naturally occurring chaperones, e.g. the prokaryotic GroEL/GroES system. Our strategy employs small molecules (“artificial chaperones”) to promote folding from the chemically denatured state (6Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1995; 117: 2373-2374Crossref Scopus (226) Google Scholar, 7Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3478-3487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar, 8Rozema D. Gellman S.H. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15760-15771Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar). Artificial chaperone-assisted folding involves a two-step protocol, which is in some ways reminiscent of the two-step binding-release mechanism of the GroEL/GroES system (9Hartl F.U. Nature. 1996; 381: 571-580Crossref PubMed Scopus (3077) Google Scholar, 10Fenton W.A. Horwich A.L. Protein Sci. 1997; 6: 743-760Crossref PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar). In the first step of the artificial chaperone protocol, a detergent is used to capture the nonnative protein upon dilution of the denaturant to nondenaturing concentrations. For proteins that are difficult to fold, denaturant dilution typically leads to hydrophobically driven protein aggregation rather than folding (1$$Google Scholar, 2$$Google Scholar, 3Jaenicke R. Seckler R. Adv. Protein Chem. 1997; 50: 1-59Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4DeBernardez-Clark E. Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. 1998; 9: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (401) Google Scholar, 5Fink A.L. Folding Design. 1998; 3: R9-R23Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1025) Google Scholar). When the artificial chaperone method is used, aggregation is prevented by the formation of protein-detergent complexes, in which hydrophobic regions of nonnative protein molecules are presumably shielded by detergent (6Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1995; 117: 2373-2374Crossref Scopus (226) Google Scholar, 7Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3478-3487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar, 8Rozema D. Gellman S.H. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15760-15771Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar). In the second step of the artificial chaperone protocol, a cyclodextrin is added. The cyclodextrin initiates folding by stripping detergent from the protein-detergent complex. This method has been shown by Couthonet al. (11Couthon F. Cottes E. Vial C. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1996; 227: 854-860Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar) to facilitate refolding of MM-creatine kinase, and an extension of the method allows generation of vesicles containing intact membrane proteins (12DeGrip W.J. VanOostrum J. Bovee-Gurts P.H.M. Biochem. J. 1998; 330: 667-673Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). As with most other studies of protein folding methodology, our studies have involved “refolding,” since the proteins employed are obtained commercially in the native state. It is generally assumed that refolding of proteins denatured from the native state should be comparable with folding of proteins solubilized by a denaturant from a misfolded form (e.g. inclusion bodies) (1$$Google Scholar, 2$$Google Scholar, 3Jaenicke R. Seckler R. Adv. Protein Chem. 1997; 50: 1-59Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4DeBernardez-Clark E. Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. 1998; 9: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (401) Google Scholar, 5Fink A.L. Folding Design. 1998; 3: R9-R23Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1025) Google Scholar). The artificial chaperone technique is mechanistically distinct from other methods that employ small molecules to promote protein refolding. One common approach has been to include low molecular weight folding assistants in the buffer that is used to dilute the chemically denatured protein (13Tandon S. Horowitz P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 955: 19-25Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar, 14Zardeneta G. Horowitz P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 5811-5816Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Wetlaufer D.B. Xie Y. Protein Sci. 1995; 4: 1535-1543Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 16Karuppiah N. Sharma A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 211: 60-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar, 17Goldberg M.E. Expert-Bezancon H. Vuillard L. Rabilloud T. Folding Design. 1996; 1: 21-27Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 18Cleland J.L. Builder S.E. Swartz J.R. Winkler M. Chang J.Y. Wang D.I.C. Bio/Technology. 1992; 10: 1013-1019Crossref PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar, 19Cleland J.L. Randolph T.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3147-3153Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In this “dilution additive” strategy, interactions between the small molecule and the folding protein must be transient, sufficient to discourage protein aggregation but not so strong as to prevent proper folding. This transient interaction in the dilution additive strategy stands in contrast to the stable interaction between nonnative protein and the detergent in the artificial chaperone method. Detergents (13Tandon S. Horowitz P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 955: 19-25Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar, 14Zardeneta G. Horowitz P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 5811-5816Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Wetlaufer D.B. Xie Y. Protein Sci. 1995; 4: 1535-1543Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar), cyclodextrins (8Rozema D. Gellman S.H. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15760-15771Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar, 16Karuppiah N. Sharma A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 211: 60-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar), sulfobetaines (17Goldberg M.E. Expert-Bezancon H. Vuillard L. Rabilloud T. Folding Design. 1996; 1: 21-27Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar), and polyethylene glycol (18Cleland J.L. Builder S.E. Swartz J.R. Winkler M. Chang J.Y. Wang D.I.C. Bio/Technology. 1992; 10: 1013-1019Crossref PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar, 19Cleland J.L. Randolph T.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 3147-3153Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have been employed as dilution additives. We discuss here the application of the artificial chaperone refolding method to porcine heart citrate synthase (CS).1 (This protein was discussed briefly in our initial report on the artificial chaperone technique (6Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1995; 117: 2373-2374Crossref Scopus (226) Google Scholar).) Artificial chaperone-assisted refolding of denatured bovine carbonic anhydrase B (CAB) (7Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3478-3487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar) and of denatured, reduced hen egg white lysozyme (8Rozema D. Gellman S.H. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15760-15771Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar) have been previously described in detail. Like CAB and lysozyme, CS is recognized to be difficult to refold, and CS has therefore been employed by others as a test case for refolding strategies. Two groups have examined the ability of GroE chaperones to promote refolding of Gdm-denatured CS (20Buchner J. Schmidt M. Fuchs M. Jaenicke R. Rudolph R. Schmid F.X. Kiefhaber T. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 1586-1591Crossref PubMed Scopus (404) Google Scholar, 21Zhi W. Landry S.J. Gierasch L.M. Srere P.A. Protein Sci. 1992; 1: 522-529Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). An attempt to achieve dilution additive assistance of CS refolding with a detergent was unsuccessful (21Zhi W. Landry S.J. Gierasch L.M. Srere P.A. Protein Sci. 1992; 1: 522-529Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). CS has no structural homology to CAB or lysozyme, and CS differs architecturally from these other two enzymes in requiring quaternary structure formation (homodimerization) for activity (22McEvily A.J. Harrison J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 2593-2598Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This requirement makes CS a particularly interesting target as we probe the versatility of the artificial chaperone refolding method. Porcine heart citrate synthase was purchased as a suspension in 3.2 m ammonium sulfate from Boehringer Mannheim; this material was used directly in all experiments described here. CTAB, ZW 3–14, POE(10)L, SDS, EDTA, DTT, acetyl-CoA, 5,5′-dithiobis(nitrobenzoic acid), and oxalacetate were purchased from Sigma. STS was purchased from Lancaster (Windham, NH). Sequanal grade GdmCl and urea were purchased from Pierce. CTAHS was purchased from Aldrich. Centricon concentrators were purchased from Amicon (Beverly, MA). Acetate filters (0.22 μm) were purchased from Fisher. Biobeads® SM-2 were purchased from Bio-Rad. Calbiosorb™ beads were purchased from Calbiosorb (La Jolla, CA). SDR HyperD® was purchased from Biosepra (Marlborough, MA). α-cyclodextrin, β-cyclodextrin, methylated β-cyclodextrin, and β-cyclodextrin-epichlorhydrin copolymer were gifts from Amaizo, Inc. (Hammond, IN). α-Cyclodextrin and β-cyclodextrin were recrystallized from water. All other materials were used as obtained from suppliers. Protein concentration of commercial suspension was verified after dilution/dissolution by absorbance at 280 nm, using an extinction coefficient of 1.75 (mg/ml protein)−1 cm−1(23Bloxham D.P. Ericsson L.H. Titani K. Walsh K.A. Neurath H. Biochemistry. 1980; 19: 3979-3985Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). The concentration of GdmCl solution was determined by measuring the refractive index (24Pace C.N. Methods Enzymol. 1986; 131: 266-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (2402) Google Scholar). In a typical GdmCl denaturation/refolding study, 2.4 mg/ml CS (as a suspension in 3.2 m ammonium sulfate) was dissolved in 6m GdmCl and 40 mm DTT and allowed to stand for 1 h. The CS solution was then diluted by a factor of 70 with Tris-chloride buffer containing detergent and EDTA to give concentrations of 0.034 mg/ml CS, 0.57 mm DTT, 86 mm GdmCl, 143 mm Tris-Cl (pH 7.6), 0.71 mm EDTA, and 0.57 mm detergent. After 1 h, 30 μl of 16 mm β-cyclodextrin stock solution was added to 70 μl of the above solution to bring the final concentrations to 0.024 mg/ml CS, 0.4 mm DTT, 60 mm GdmCl, 100 mm Tris-Cl, 0.5 mm EDTA, 0.4 mmdetergent, and 4.8 mm β-cyclodextrin. This solution also contained 100 mm ammonium sulfate from the original suspension; when CS was desalted before use, refolding yields were not substantially changed (desalted CS could not be stored for long periods). After sitting overnight, the solutions were assayed for enzymatic activity. In a typical urea denaturation/refolding study, 0.8 mg/ml CS (as a suspension in 3.2 m ammonium sulfate) was dissolved in 8m urea and 13.3 mm DTT and allowed to stand for 1 h. The CS solution was then diluted by a factor of 24 with Tris-chloride buffer containing detergent to give concentrations of 0.034 mg/ml CS, 0.57 mm DTT, 340 mm urea, 143 mm Tris-Cl (pH 7.6), 0.71 mm EDTA, and 0.57 mm detergent. After 1 h, 16 mmβ-cyclodextrin stock solution was added to bring the final concentrations to 0.024 mg/ml CS, 0.4 mm DTT, 240 mm urea, 100 mm Tris-Cl, 0.5 mmEDTA, 0.4 mm detergent, 4.8 mmβ-cyclodextrin, and 100 mm ammonium sulfate. After sitting overnight, the solutions were assayed for enzymatic activity. For some studies, β-cyclodextrin was added in two parts. The first addition was 1 h after dilution with detergent solution, and the second addition was 10, 200, or 800 min after the first β-cyclodextrin addition. The total volume of β-cyclodextrin solution added was equal in all cases and resulted in solutions of 0.024 mg/ml, 0.4 mm detergent, and a β-cyclodextrin concentration that was optimal for the detergent in question (see Fig.4). CTAB requires 12 equivalents, ZW 3–14 requires 2 equivalents, and POE(10)L and Triton X-100 require 4 equivalents of cyclodextrin. Activity of the CS solutions was determined using an acetyl coenzyme A assay (25Srere P.A. Brazil H. Gonen L. Acta Chemica Scandinavica. 1963; 17: S129-S134Crossref Google Scholar) in which 20 μl of the final CS solution was added to 380 μl of a solution containing 158 mm Tris-Cl (pH 7.6), 0.023 mm acetyl-CoA, 0.5 mm oxalacetate, and 0.12 mm 5,5′-dithiobis(nitrobenzoic acid). The final solution contained 0.0012 mg/ml CS, 150 mm Tris-Cl (pH 7.6), 0.02 mm DTT, 3 mm GdmCl, 0.025 mm EDTA, 0.02 mm detergent, 0.024 mm β-cyclodextrin, 0.022 μm acetyl-CoA, 0.48 mm oxalacetate, and 0.11 mm5,5′-dithiobis(nitrobenzoic acid). After 10 s of mixing, the increase in absorbance at 412 nm was measured as a function of time. The absorbance of the solution was measured every 0.5 s for 30 s using a model 8452 diode array spectrophotometer (Hewlett-Packard, Mountain View, CA). The initial rate of the change in absorbance was always linear. A 62A DS CD spectrophotometer (AVIV) was used for CD analysis. For far UV (200–260 nm), 1-mm path length cells were used. For near UV (260–320 nm), 10-mm path length cells were used. Spectra were obtained with one scan, 10-s averaging time, at room temperature. For all samples analyzed by CD, the final Tris-Cl concentration was reduced to 30 mm to minimize absorbance of the buffer at low wavelengths. Control studies showed that the lower buffer concentration did not significantly alter the refolding results. For each sample, a CD spectrum of a reference sample containing Tris-Cl buffer, detergent, and cyclodextrin was subtracted. Light scattering was measured using an F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer (Hitachi Instruments, Inc., Naperville, IL). Samples were prepared from stock solutions that had been filtered through a 0.22-μm acetate filter. Irradiation and detection wavelengths were 350 nm, and a 3 × 3-mm cuvette was used. The CMC of each detergent under refolding conditions was determined by rocking solid orange OT in a 0.3-ml aliquot containing 100 mm Tris-Cl (pH 7.6), 0.5 mm EDTA and various concentrations of the detergent (37Eriksson A.E. Jones T.A. Liljas A. Proteins Struct. Funct. Genet. 1988; 4: 274-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (504) Google Scholar). After 2 days, a cotton plug was used to filter off the undissolved orange OT. The filtrate was diluted by a factor of 4 with ethanol. The absorbance was measured at 500 nm in a 10-mm path length cuvette. The absorbance was plotted as a function of detergent concentration. Two linear regions were observed, the intersection of which was taken to define the CMC of the detergent. CS was isolated after refolding by filtering 1.0 ml of CS solution through a 0.22-μm acetate filter to remove aggregated proteins. The filtrate was then concentrated to a volume of 0.5 ml with a 10,000 molecular weight cut-off Centricon filter. Refolded CS solutions were then compared with native CS solutions by absorbance at 280 nm and specific activity. A stirred solution of 4-tert-octylphenol (0.56 g, 2.7 mmol) in dry CH3OH (15 ml) was treated with KOH (1.218 g, 22 mmol). After 15 min, all volatiles were removed in vacuo. The residue was dissolved in dry CH3CN (35 ml) and treated with 3-bromo-1-propanol (0.25 ml, 2.8 mmol) followed by overnight stirring. Removal of solids by filtration and chromatographic purification (silica; 30% EtOAc/hexane, R F = 0.2) gave 3-(4-tert-octylphenoxy)-1-propanol as a clear oil (0.63 g, 88%). This alcohol (0.58 g, 2.2 mmol) and CBr4 (0.96 g, 2.9 mmol) were dissolved in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (40 ml) and treated dropwise with a solution of PPh3 (0.73 g, 2.9 mmol) in tetrahydrofuran (30 ml). The removal of solids by filtration after overnight stirring and chromatographic purification of the residue after solvent removal (silica; 10% EtOAc/hexane,R F = 0.9) gave 1-bromo-3-(4-tert-octylphenoxy)propane as a clear oil (0.44 g, 62%). 1-Bromo-3-(4-tert-octylphenoxy)propane (4.56 g, 13.9 mmol) in anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (120 ml) was treated with an excess of Me2NH in tetrahydrofuran (10 ml). After 24 h, the reaction mixture was washed with brine and dried over MgSO4. The solvent was removed, and the residue was purified on silica gel (6% NH3-saturated MeOH in CHCl3, R F = 0.2) to giveN-(3-(4-tert-butylphenoxy)-N,N-dimethylamine as a clear oil (3.52 g, 87%). Overnight reflux of this amine (1.1 g, 4.7 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (8 ml) with 1,3-propanesultone (0.39 ml, 4.5 mmol) gave the desired detergent as a white solid, isolated by filtration under N2. Both structures were verified by x-ray crystallography. The results of CS refolding experiments and the appropriate controls are shown in Table I in terms of enzymatic activity (initial catalytic rates). All measurements were normalized to native CS activity. When 2.4 mg/ml CS was denatured with 6m GdmCl or 8 m urea and 40 mm DTT for 1 h and then diluted 100-fold, only 5–7% of the original CS activity was recovered. Light scattering analysis indicates that extensive protein aggregation occurs under these conditions. Thus, denaturation effectively inactivates CS, and simple dilution of chemically denatured protein leads to very little unassisted refolding, which is consistent with previous reports (20Buchner J. Schmidt M. Fuchs M. Jaenicke R. Rudolph R. Schmid F.X. Kiefhaber T. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 1586-1591Crossref PubMed Scopus (404) Google Scholar, 21Zhi W. Landry S.J. Gierasch L.M. Srere P.A. Protein Sci. 1992; 1: 522-529Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). In contrast, dilution in the presence of detergent, followed by the addition of cyclodextrin to the CS-detergent complexes provides approximately 60% recovery of native CS activity. Light scattering studies indicate that some of the protein aggregates upon the addition of cyclodextrin to CS-detergent complexes, which would account for the incomplete regain of native activity. Thus, stripping of detergent from the nonnative protein initiates a competition between proper refolding and aggregation. The optimal CS refolding yield is lower than optimal yields obtained for CAB (7Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3478-3487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar) and lysozyme (8Rozema D. Gellman S.H. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15760-15771Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar) at similar concentrations with the artificial chaperone method. It is noteworthy that CS refolding is successful with detergents from several classes, including cationic (CTAB), zwitterionic (ZW 3–14) and nonionic (POE(10)L and Triton X-100), because CAB (7Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3478-3487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar) and lysozyme (8Rozema D. Gellman S.H. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15760-15771Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar) refolding require ionic or zwitterionic detergents for success. Nonionic detergents initially appeared to be optimal for CS refolding, with CTAB decidedly inferior (6Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1995; 117: 2373-2374Crossref Scopus (226) Google Scholar). We have subsequently discovered that CTAB is indeed a successful artificial chaperone for CS if sufficient cyclodextrin is used at the stripping step; CTAB requires proportionally more cyclodextrin than do nonionic detergents (this point is discussed further below). Anionic detergents SDS and STS are successful artificial chaperones for refolding of urea-denatured CAB 2Hanson, P. E., and Gellman, S. H. (1998)Folding & Design, in press. ; however, neither SDS nor STS is an effective artificial chaperone for urea-denatured CS (data not shown). (These anionic detergents cannot be used with Gdm-denatured proteins because the guanidinium-alkylsulfate salts precipitate.) We prepared two new zwitterionic detergents, 1 and2 (Scheme FS1), for evaluation as artificial chaperones. Detergent 1 contains thep-t-octylphenyl unit that is found in Triton X-100; 2 contains a p-t-butylphenyl unit for enhanced aqueous solubility relative to 1. We have previously reported that anionic and cationic derivatives of Triton X-100 can promote CAB (7Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3478-3487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar) and lysozyme (8Rozema D. Gellman S.H. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15760-15771Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar) refolding (the anionic derivative is now commercially available from Calbiochem). The susceptibility of CS to refolding assistance with other zwitterionic detergents provided an opportunity to complete our series ofp-t-butylphenyl-based detergents. CMC values of ∼0.6 mm for 1 and ∼1.5 mm for2 in water were estimated by the orange OT solubilization method (28Schott H. J. Phys. Chem. 1964; 68: 3612-3619Crossref Scopus (23) Google Scholar). The similarity of CMC values contrasted with a profound difference in aqueous solubilities (∼5 mm for1 versus 1.4 m for 2). Neither of these new detergents assisted CS refolding in the artificial chaperone mode. Control studies demonstrate that CS refolding is not promoted by either detergents or cyclodextrins via the dilution additive mechanism under the conditions we employ for artificial chaperone-assisted refolding. Data in Table I show that simply diluting chemically denatured CS in the presence of detergents gives only 2–7% regained enzymatic activity, i.e. that there is no improvement relative to dilution in the absence of detergent. These results are consistent with the findings of Zhi et al. (21Zhi W. Landry S.J. Gierasch L.M. Srere P.A. Protein Sci. 1992; 1: 522-529Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar), who were unable to promote refolding of chemically denatured CS with lauryl maltoside as a dilution additive. It has been reported that refolding of Gdm-denatured CAB can be enhanced by using high concentrations of cyclodextrin as a dilution additive (16Karuppiah N. Sharma A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 211: 60-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar). We find a maximum of 25% regain of CS activity when the dilution buffer contains 100 mm methylated β-cyclodextrin, and this regain diminishes to 16% for 25 mm methylated β-cyclodextrin (protein concentration, buffer, etc. as described in Table I). The very modest CS refolding efficacy of cyclodextrin in the dilution additive mode parallels our earlier findings with CAB (7Rozema D. Gellman S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 3478-3487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar). Cleland et al. (18Cleland J.L. Builder S.E. Swartz J.R. Winkler M. Chang J.Y. Wang D.I.C. Bio/Technology. 1992; 10: 1013-1019Crossref PubM

Flavohemoglobins, a family of two-domain proteins with homology to vertebrate hemoglobins, are found in a variety of prokaryotic and eukaryotic microorganisms. Recent studies suggest a role for these proteins in nitrogen oxide metabolism. We now show that nitric oxide donors positively regulate a chromosomal flavohemoglobin (hmp)/lacZ operon fusion in Salmonella typhimurium. hmp gene expression in the presence of NO⋅ is independent of the SoxS, OxyR, and FNR transcription factors and instead relies on inactivation of the iron-dependent Fur repressor. Other Fur-repressed promoters in S. typhimuriumare also activated by an NO⋅ donor. In contrast to the wild-type strain, an hmp − mutant requires markedly lower concentrations of NO to induce the hmp/lacZ fusion, whereas its response to iron chelation is equivalent to wild type. These data unveil a new pathway for NO-dependent gene expression inS. typhimurium. Flavohemoglobins, a family of two-domain proteins with homology to vertebrate hemoglobins, are found in a variety of prokaryotic and eukaryotic microorganisms. Recent studies suggest a role for these proteins in nitrogen oxide metabolism. We now show that nitric oxide donors positively regulate a chromosomal flavohemoglobin (hmp)/lacZ operon fusion in Salmonella typhimurium. hmp gene expression in the presence of NO⋅ is independent of the SoxS, OxyR, and FNR transcription factors and instead relies on inactivation of the iron-dependent Fur repressor. Other Fur-repressed promoters in S. typhimuriumare also activated by an NO⋅ donor. In contrast to the wild-type strain, an hmp − mutant requires markedly lower concentrations of NO to induce the hmp/lacZ fusion, whereas its response to iron chelation is equivalent to wild type. These data unveil a new pathway for NO-dependent gene expression inS. typhimurium. Regulation of the Salmonella typhimuriumflavohemoglobin gene. A new pathway for bacterial gene expression in response to nitric oxide.Journal of Biological ChemistryVol. 274Issue 6PreviewPage 34029, “Experimental Procedures”: The greek symbols were not inserted so the E. coli strain listed as S17-1 1pir should be S17-1 λpir, and the concentrations of the antibiotics ampicillin, kanamycin, chloramphenicol, and tetracycline should read “μg/ml” rather than “mg/ml.” Full-Text PDF Open Access nitric oxide S-nitrosoglutathione 2,2′-(hydroxynitrosohydrazono)bisethanamine fur titration assay. In addition to its function as a regulatory molecule in organisms ranging from humans to slime molds, nitric oxide possesses potent and broad spectrum antimicrobial activity (1Fang F.C. J. Clin. Invest. 1997; 99: 2818-2825Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The cellular targets responsible for the cytocidal and/or cytostatic action of NO1 include lipids, thiols, DNA, and transition metals. A growing body of evidence indicates that bacteria are capable of inducing protective enzymes in the presence of NO and other reactive nitrogen intermediates, a process recently termed the nitrosative stress response (2Hausladen A. Privalle C.T. Keng T. DeAngelo J. Stamler J.S. Cell. 1996; 86: 719-729Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar). The SoxRS system, which is activated by superoxide generators, will stimulate antioxidant genes in reaction to NO⋅ and defend Escherichia coli from the NO-dependent bactericidal activity of macrophages (3Nunoshiba T. DeRojas-Walker T. Wishnok J.S. Tannenbaum S.R. Demple B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 9993-9997Crossref PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar). OxyR, a transcription factor involved in stimulation of peroxide detoxification genes, is directly modified by NO viaS-nitrosylation and assists in protecting the bacterium from the NO donor S-nitrosocysteine (2Hausladen A. Privalle C.T. Keng T. DeAngelo J. Stamler J.S. Cell. 1996; 86: 719-729Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar). Alkyl hydroperoxide reductase subunit C, one of the enzymes influenced by OxyR, has been shown to protect Salmonella typhimurium from another NO donor, S-nitrosoglutathione (GSNO) (4Chen L. Xie Q.-W. Nathan C. Mol. Cell. 1998; 1: 795-805Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (171) Google Scholar). Deletion of flavohemoglobin, a two-domain protein with N-terminal homology to hemoglobins and C-terminal homology to oxidoreductases, also results in hypersensitivity of S. typhimurium to nitrosative stress (5Crawford M.J. Goldberg D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 12543-12547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar). The mutant strain is equivalent to wild-type in sensitivities to superoxide and hydrogen peroxide, suggesting the existence of a nitrosative stress response that is independent of the oxygen-related stress pathways. Flavohemoglobins have been isolated from phylogenetically distant organisms, including Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Bacillus subtilis, and E. coli (6Zhu H. Riggs A.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 5015-5019Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 7LaCelle M. Kumano M. Kurita K. Yamane K. Zuber P. Nakano M.M. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 3803-3808Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 8Vasudevan S.G. Armarego W.L.F. Shaw D.C. Lilley P.E. Dixon N.E. Poole R.K. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1991; 226: 49-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). Although the promoter activities of some flavohemoglobins are influenced by oxygen availability (7LaCelle M. Kumano M. Kurita K. Yamane K. Zuber P. Nakano M.M. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 3803-3808Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Crawford M.J. Sherman D.R. Goldberg D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 6991-6996Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar), nitrogen oxides are known to induce the transcription of these proteins in other organisms. Flavohemoglobin in the fungus Fusarium oxysporum is present only during denitrification, an anaerobic electron transport pathway that reduces nitrate to dinitrogen via nitrogen oxide intermediates (10Takaya N. Suzuki S. Matsuo M. Shoun H. FEBS Lett. 1997; 414: 545-548Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). A flavohemoglobin mutant strain of the denitrifying bacteriumAlcaligenes eutrophus is deficient in the transient production of nitrous oxide (N2O), an intermediate that is immediately downstream of NO⋅ in the denitrification pathway (11Cramm R. Siddiqui R.A. Friedrich B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7349-7354Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Many other flavohemoglobin-containing organisms do not have the denitrifying capability of F. oxysporum or A. eutrophus. Some, such as E. coli and B. subtilis, will reduce nitrite to ammonia or ammonium rather than nitric oxide (12Cole J. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 1996; 136: 1-11Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 13Ogawa K. Akagawa E. Yamane K. Sun Z.W. LaCelle M. Zuper P. Nakano M. J. Bacteriol. 1995; 177: 1409-1413Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Nevertheless, purified NO⋅ was found to be a major inducer of flavohemoglobin (hmp) promoter activity in E. coli (14Poole R.K. Anjum M.F. Membrillo-Hernandez J. Kim S.O. Hughes M.N. Stewart V. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5487-5492Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). An hmp/lacZ operon fusion was stimulated approximately 20-fold by 20 μmnitric oxide, while requiring 8 mm nitrite and 40 mm nitrate to give similar results. Unlike the nitrite and nitrate effects, which are escalated anaerobically, the NO⋅induction is largely independent of O2 concentration. TheB. subtilis hmp is also induced by comparable levels of nitrite, but the influence of nitric oxide was not reported (7LaCelle M. Kumano M. Kurita K. Yamane K. Zuber P. Nakano M.M. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 3803-3808Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, purified E. coli flavohemoglobin was demonstrated to oxidize NO⋅ to the less toxic nitrate (15Gardner P.R. Gardner A.M. Martin L.A. Salzman A.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 10378-10383Crossref PubMed Scopus (497) Google Scholar), thus assigning an enzymatic activity to the nitrosative stress protection shown by phenotypic analyses (5Crawford M.J. Goldberg D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 12543-12547Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar). The elements responsible for the NO⋅-dependent expression of flavohemoglobins are not known. Although the ResDE two-component system accounts for some of the anaerobic expression ofhmp in B. subtilis, factors contributing to the nitrite induction were not elucidated (7LaCelle M. Kumano M. Kurita K. Yamane K. Zuber P. Nakano M.M. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 3803-3808Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). E. coli strains harboring null alleles of narL and narP, which regulate nitrate and nitrite reductases, do not substantially alterhmp expression (14Poole R.K. Anjum M.F. Membrillo-Hernandez J. Kim S.O. Hughes M.N. Stewart V. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5487-5492Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). FNR, a transcription factor known to positively regulate a flavohemoglobin homolog in the bacteriumVitreoscilla as well as many denitrification enzymes in other species, actually represses anaerobic expression of the E. coli hmp (14Poole R.K. Anjum M.F. Membrillo-Hernandez J. Kim S.O. Hughes M.N. Stewart V. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5487-5492Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar, 16Joshi M. Dikshit K.L. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1994; 202: 535-542Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 17Zumft W. Microbiol. Mol. Biol. Rev. 1997; 61: 533-616Crossref PubMed Scopus (2897) Google Scholar). The NO⋅ expression is also largely independent of the SoxRS system in E. coli (14Poole R.K. Anjum M.F. Membrillo-Hernandez J. Kim S.O. Hughes M.N. Stewart V. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5487-5492Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). In addition to nitrogen oxides, the iron chelator 2,2′-dipyridyl significantly enhances E. coli hmp expression. This induction was tentatively attributed to deactivation of FNR, which requires iron for function (14Poole R.K. Anjum M.F. Membrillo-Hernandez J. Kim S.O. Hughes M.N. Stewart V. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5487-5492Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). In this study, we have found that the S. typhimurium hmpgene expression is induced by the NO donors and that the transcriptional repressor Fur is the primary factor responsible forhmp regulation. Nitric oxide causes a general derepression of other Fur-regulated genes, suggesting a new mechanism of NO action on bacterial gene expression. Open table in a new tab All liquid cultures were grown in LB broth. When necessary, antibiotics were added at the following concentrations: 100 mg/ml ampicillin, 50 mg/ml kanamycin, 25 mg/ml chloramphenicol, 15 mg/ml tetracycline. For SPER/NO growth curves, 250 ml of bacteria from an overnight culture was inoculated into a 125-ml culture flask containing 25 ml of medium. The bacteria were then allowed to grow at 37 °C for 1 h with 225 rpm shaking before the introduction of 1 mm SPER/NO. Turbidities were followed using a Klett colorimeter. For gene expression studies, overnight cultures were diluted 1/100 into test tubes containing 2 ml of medium and were shaken at 37 °C for 1.5 h. Unless otherwise indicated, 1 mm SPER/NO or 0.2 mm 2,2′-dipyridyl was introduced, and the cultures were allowed to incubate for another 2 h. To stop gene expression, 300 mg/ml spectinomycin was added 5 min before harvesting. Cells were pelleted, resuspended in Z buffer (23Miller J. Experiments in Molecular Genetics. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1972: 352-355Google Scholar), and permeabilized with sodium dodecyl sulfate and chloroform. β-Galactosidase activities, which were assayed in triplicate, are expressed as Miller units (23Miller J. Experiments in Molecular Genetics. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1972: 352-355Google Scholar). All experiments were performed at least three times with two independently isolated clones. For the Fur titration assay, bacteria from overnight cultures were streaked onto MacConkey agar with ampicillin and incubated overnight at 37 °C (24Stojiljkovic I. Baumler A. Hantke K. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 236: 531-545Crossref PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar). To facilitate gene expression studies on hmp, we used an S. typhimurium strain harboring a single copy of an hmp/lacZ operon fusion. The expression construct contains 920 base pairs of hmp upstream sequence fused to the promoterless lacZYA operon in the suicide plasmid pFUSE (19Baumler A. Tsolis R. van der Velden A. Stojiljkovic I. Anic S. Heffron F. Gene (Amst.). 1996; 183: 207-213Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar). As confirmed by Southern as well as by phenotypic analyses using NO donors (not shown), the endogenous hmp gene was not affected by this integration event. Spermine NONOate (SPER/NO), a well characterized NO⋅ donor (25Hirasaki A. Jones K. Perkins W. Warner D. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1996; 278: 1269-1275PubMed Google Scholar, 26Maragos C. Wang J. Hrabie J. Oppenheim J. Keefer L. Cancer Res. 1993; 53: 564-568PubMed Google Scholar), was employed to determine sensitivities of wild-type and hmp − strains as well as hmp promoter activity in response to nitric oxide. Using 1 mm SPER/NO, a growth delay is observed for both strains but is much more pronounced in the hmp −mutant (Fig. 1). Addition of SPER/NO induces the hmp promoter approximately 20-fold (Fig.2). We examined the transcription factors known to respond to nitric oxide (SoxS and OxyR) or to influencehmp transcription in E. coli (Fnr) for their contribution to aerobic hmp expression in S. typhimurium (2Hausladen A. Privalle C.T. Keng T. DeAngelo J. Stamler J.S. Cell. 1996; 86: 719-729Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar, 15Gardner P.R. Gardner A.M. Martin L.A. Salzman A.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 10378-10383Crossref PubMed Scopus (497) Google Scholar, 27Nunoshiba T. DeRojas-Walker T. Tannenbaum S.R. Demple B. Infect. Immun. 1995; 63: 794-798Crossref PubMed Google Scholar).
